source.be23a796:
import calmap
import numpy as np
f = plt.figure(figsize=(20,10))
all_days = pd.date_range('1/1/2018', periods=700, freq='D')
days = np.random.choice(all_days, 100)
events = pd.Series(np.random.randn(len(days)), index=days)
calmap.yearplot(events, year=2019)

source.5482879c:
corrmat = df_house_price.corr()
f, ax = plt.subplots(figsize=(12, 9))

source.82eae29e:
k= 11
cols = corrmat.nlargest(k,'SalePrice')['SalePrice'].index

cm = np.corrcoef(df_house_price[cols].values.T)
f , ax = plt.subplots(figsize = (14,12))
sns.heatmap(cm, vmax=.8, linewidths=0.01,square=True,annot=True,cmap='viridis',
            linecolor="white",xticklabels = cols.values ,annot_kws = {'size':12},yticklabels = cols.values)
source.34554bac:
# Pie Chart
Pie charts are a visual way of displaying data that might otherwise be given in a small table. Pie charts are useful for displaying data that are classified into nominal or ordinal categories.
source.ee939520:
# Boxen Plot
The Boxen plot is very similar to box plot, except for the fact that it plots different quartile values. By plotting different quartile values, we are able to understand the shape of the distribution particularly in the head end and tail end
source.b3afb390:
# swarmplot
This function is similar to stripplot, but the points are adjusted (only along the categorical axis) so that they don't overlap. This gives a better representation of the distribution of values,
source.e8a2f638:
# Scatter Plot
scatter plot  uses dots to represent values for two different numeric variables. The position of each dot on the horizontal and vertical axis indicates values for an individual data point.
source.eb923b2f:
# Point Plot
Point plots can be more useful than bar plots for focusing comparisons between different levels of one or more categorical variables.A point plot represents an estimate of central tendency for a numeric variable by the position of scatter plot points and provides some indication of the uncertainty around that estimate using error bars.
source.ae33bee2: Seaborn's jointplot displays a relationship between 2 variables (bivariate) as well as 1D profiles (univariate) in the margins. This plot is a convenience class that wraps JointGrid.
source.ab25c19e:
# stripplot
A strip plot is a scatter plot where one of the variables is categorical. They can be combined with other plots to provide additional information.

source.77d54c82:
# Bar Plot

A bar chart or bar graph is a chart or graph that presents categorical data with rectangular bars with heights or lengths proportional to the values that they represent. The bars can be plotted vertically or horizontally.


1. using Seaborn libary
source.43820400:
# Violin plots
A violin plot is a method of plotting numeric data. It is similar to a box plot, with the addition of a rotated kernel density plot on each side.
source.84b5e748:
# Histogram
Histograms are used to show distributions of variables while bar charts are used to compare variables. Histograms plot quantitative data with ranges of the data grouped into bins or intervals while bar charts plot categorical data
source.b49802ae: The missingno correlation heatmap measures nullity correlation: how strongly the presence or absence of one variable affects the presence of another:
source.d49cdb6e:
# Data Visualisation Techinques
![](https://www.boldbi.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/07/data-visualization@1x_2.jpg)

Data visualization is the act of taking information (data) and placing it into a visual context, such as a map or graph. Data visualizations make big and small data easier for the human brain to understand, and visualization also makes it easier to detect patterns, trends, and outliers in groups of data.

In this notebook I tried to plot different data visualisation techinques using the data sets from the competions:
1. Titanic: Machine Learning from Disaster
2. House Prices: Advanced Regression Techniques

And this notebook includes the following visualizations:

*  BarPlot
*  CountPlot
*  Pie Chart
*  calander Plot
*  Histogram
*  scatter Plot
*  Box plot
*  Stripp plot
*  Swarm Plot
*  Boxen Plot
*  Voilen Plot
*  Point Plot
*  Dis Plot
*  Reg Plot
*  KdePlot
*  Join Plot
*  HeatMaps
     
*NB: This is only the first version of the notebook more plots should be added soon     *

# Count Plot

source.c15197b9:
# BoxPlot
For some distributions/datasets, you will find that you need more information than the measures of central tendency (median, mean, and mode). Boxplots are a standardized way of displaying the distribution of data based on a five number summary (“minimum”, first quartile (Q1), median, third quartile (Q3), and “maximum”).

# kdeplot
Kernel Density Estimate is used for visualizing the Probability Density of a continuous variable.
